text: I now pronounce you both legally married
Donald Trump has said he doesn't support
same-sex marriage and many in his party
don't either but since winning the
election mr. Trump has said the law has
been settled and that he's fine with
that but we know that he's prone to
changing his mind on policies so what
can Trump do on gay rights president
Trump would not have the ability to
change the same-sex marriage ruling that
is an issue of constitutional law the
United States Supreme Court established
that right the president Trump can
influence who sits on the US Supreme
Court and he's already said he wants to
pick a conservative judge to fill the
courts current vacancy but even so it
would take a lot for the issue of gay
marriage to be brought back in front of
the Supreme Court people would have to
go through the trial court which would
have to hold a trial then it would have
to be appeal to the appellate court and
only then would it be petitioned to the
United States Supreme Court so it's
highly unlikely that gay marriage would
be reversed
cancel every unconstitutional executive
action memorandum and order issued by
President Obama that could include
undoing a law brought in by President
Obama to protect LGBTQ people from
discrimination in the workplace the
First Amendment Defense Act protects
people who don't believe in gay marriage
from losing out on government grants and
benefits critics see this as a license
to discriminate and think that if the
law is passed by Congress it could allow
businesses to deny same-sex couples
services and housing protect our LGBTQ
citizens despite an apparent softening
of his tone towards gay people at the
Republican convention Donald Trump is
surrounded by advisers including his
vice president Mike Pence who are
staunchly against furthering gay rights
and could be influential as he governs
